title: Thursday, 16th August 2018
bodyHTML:
11:03 am
BE11:04am

I think it was Samuel Johnson who said, "never agree to a morning meeting in Imperial Wharf.

Blank canvas good morning everyone
Grouchmonkey Morning. any detail n the LoLBO subpoena?
Soundbuy Hello all...........
Manxish Morning each
LK Hyman Morning all. @BE are you sure yesterday's Thames bird was a black swan? It looked more like a cormorant to me.
BE11:05am

"For Imperial Wharf truly is the rot end of London, a high rise concrete perineum betwixt Clapham and Chelsea from which a person cannot commute back to civilisation without investing an hour on the bloody Overground.

BE11:06am

"Like and subscribe, y'all."

11:06 am
BE11:06am

So, today's ML is being brought to you from here:

BE11:06am

LK Hyman Or possibly a shag

The cafe round the side of a Tesco Metro.

Patience Good morning
J L Morning

Apologies for raggedness. Blame Harris & Hoole's internet.

undefined
Jarhead G'morning from South Afica
Patience @LK Hyman - markets mistook it for a black swan :-(
Soundbuy No Mayfair?? Jeez...........what's happened?
BE11:08am

First things first ... @LK Hyman, I checked back with the primary source, who swears it was a swan.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

And was quite offended that people were questioning his ornithological chops.

Soundbuy Nice to see you've given your manservant waterproofs though, thoughtful
BE11:09am

Nevertheless, it remains single sourced. And under FT rules we must therefore classify it as RAW

Soundbuy Making him stand outside......hmmm
Badger So anything on Inmarsat? (honestly, just a joke).
undefined
11:10 am
BE11:10am

Should we do some markets then?

Badger Any thoughts on delayed accounting at Allied Minds? Or is that one for PM?
BE11:11am

Here seems as good a place to start as any: https://www.reuter...rces-idUSKBN1L10HS

BE11:11am

LONDON (Reuters) - Amazon.com Inc (AMZN.O) is sounding out some of Europe’s top insurance firms to see if they would contribute products to a UK price comparison website in what would be a major foray by the U.S. online retail giant into the region’s financial services.

Excel Developer retail sales recovered.
Soundbuy I'm having trouble these days identifying risk on/risk off days.....
11:12 am
BE11:12am

Three industry executives told Reuters they had held talks with Amazon about the possible launch of a site. One said the talks were part of several discussions Amazon is having with insurers. A second said there were no imminent launch plans.

While it was not immediately clear what type of insurance would be sold on any Amazon site, home and motor policies are popular sellers on existing UK price comparison sites.

casapinos @LK it's easy to mistake a shag for something else!!
LK Hyman I stand corrected, but a black swan has a big red patch on its beak and that fowl didn't have one.
JuB any update SKY LN process ?
Moneysupermarket.Com Group PLC (MONY:LSE): Last: 289.35, down 9.85 (-3.29%), High: 291.40, Low: 285.20, Volume: 822.00k
JD Re PCW: Didn't Google try the same thing a couple of years back? Cancelled due to lack of interest if I recall
Admiral Group PLC (ADM:LSE): Last: 2,032, down 30 (-1.45%), High: 2,050, Low: 2,012, Volume: 274.61k
11:13 am
Gocompare.Com Group PLC (GOCO:LSE): Last: 112.40, down 1.6 (-1.40%), High: 113.40, Low: 102.40, Volume: 212.24k

We've been down this road several times before.

Scalper anyone following BlueJay Mining? Bear raid?
Soundbuy Gocompare - quite a low there eralier
Soundbuy *earlier
J Chisholm LK Hyman. I can assure you it was a swan. I was 20 yards away when I took the photo. The Shad Thames cormorants have dwindled in number this summer and they steer well clear of the swans.
BE11:15am

Usually with Rightmove and various US groups trying to step into the house listing business.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

They have, generally speaking, failed.

Flaneur Insurance would give Amazon a really, really deep insight into peoples lives, wouldnt it?
BE11:16am

Google's history is littered with failed experiments to do price comparison. And clearly, the European Court antitrust judgement against them has reined in their ambitions a bit for now.

JD Why doesn't Amazon just buy MONY or GOCO? You get the people, know-how. Goco seems dirt cheap in any case
BE11:17am

Course, as @Flaneur notes, Amazon's ambitions might be more on the data mining side than the commission side ......

11:17 am
BE11:17am

..... which'd make it a pretty aggressive competitor. Possibly.

Sails @Flaneur as would Doctor Alexa
BE11:18am

This is from Panmure's morning sales thing:

BE11:18am

Discussions only, no imminent launch, but...the big bogeyman raises his head for MONY,
GOCO as well as private guys (CompareTheMarket etc). While it's true that Google and FB have both
tried and failed in other price comparison sectors previously (autos, shopping) the financial services
PCW sector is more spread out (with several names spending heavily on marketing to grab customers
- eg Moneysupermarket/CTM ads) - so market likely to take this seriously and mark MONY (and GOCO) down significantly.

11:19 am
undefined

Just catching up on comments ...... Tesla, all the details we have are here: https://www.ft.com...-85da-eeb7a9ce36e4

BE11:21am

And just as a sidenote, we should probably stop calling it a loLBO

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Because it's even dumber than that. It's a sort-of take private, but not really, and a sort of delisting, but not really.

BE11:22am

It's a sort of nothing is what it is.

BE11:23am

Though I note, incidentally, that Goldman Sachs suspended coverage yesterday ....

11:23 am
BE11:24am

The Americas Investment Review Committee has determined that the ratings and price target for Tesla Inc. should be removed. Goldman Sachs is acting as a financial advisor in connection with a matter that is fundamental to the reasonable analysis of the rating and price target for this stock. This “Not Rated” status will continue until such time as sufficient information is available, and/or contingencies appear resolved, to allow such analysis. Earnings estimates during this period will be made without regard to the proposed matter.

BE11:24am

Hm .................

wayneJ Perhaps Amazon ought to go whole hog and buy the NHS....
wayneJ And issue its own currency....
BE11:26am

Perhaps should've done that earlier. Such as when Musk announced that Goldman and Silver Lake were working on the "take private", several days ago.

11:26 am
undefined
BE11:28am

Allied Minds .... I know nothing! And avoid talking about it generally! However .....

BE11:28am

Here's one interpretation ...... From Jefferies:

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Delaying 1H18 results ... to the latest possible date [on or before 28th September] hopefully means that discussions to avert write-downs or closures of some of the top investments are still genuinely active.

Pharma Not sure "averting write-downs or closures" is a positive. Sounds more like a fudge.
BE11:30am

[M]ultiple events are awaited/overdue: STT’s (34% of PV) Series B/partners originally due end 2017, SciFluor’s (23%) partnering/funding for Ph2 and an IND, FedWireless (16%) FCC certification, Precision Biopsy (16%) trial and CE mark. Delaying results from 16th August to at latest 28th Sept offers hope that some can be achieved as cash dwindles: maintain Hold.

Excel Developer are you still fighting over a bird?
Allied Minds PLC (ALM:LSE): Last: 80.67, up 0.365 (+0.45%), High: 80.67, Low: 79.30, Volume: 62.77k
11:31 am
BE11:32am

One of Paul Murphy's favourite phrases was, "it takes longer to add up bad numbers than good ones" .....

hhhhiiii hi
Grouchmonkey PM right on the money, there
BE11:32am

..... and Allied Minds' numbers are largely outdated, with progress lacking in rebuilding the funding model, so .....

BE11:33am

.... bit more Jefferies:

Pharma *was*??! Is there something we should be told?
11:33 am
BE11:33am

STT’s $70m October 2014 round set a ~$250m valuation, and this seems to have been left unchanged in the December 2017 bridge after the planned $50m Series B missed its deadline (still missing in action despite being ‘in active discussions’ at the finals in April 2018 - as we wrote last month, despite plenty of MRAM interest, major fabs all have partners and STT appears not to be attracting deals). SciFluor was valued at an estimated ~$130m at an April 2015 $30m round, and despite reading out its Ph1’s for SF0166 (Sept 2017 for DME and Dec 2017 for Wet AMD) no progress on advancing to Ph2 or funding/partnering has emerged. Precision Biopsy was valued at an estimated $96m in an October 2015 $34m Series B and its goals for 2018 of completing the Cohort B and achieving a CE mark are still in process. Federated Wireless remains the only top four portfolio company that looks to be progressing – its $42m Sept 2017 Series B didn’t produce any FV gain (we estimate a company value of ~$122m) but brought in stellar investor/partners: Charter Comms, Arris, American Tower alongside GIC and Allied Minds itself.

BE11:34am

(@Pharma: just FT style. We don't like present tense. No need for alarm.)

BE11:34am

Pick your own narrative out of that lot.

11:34 am
undefined
BE11:35am

Update on Harris & Hoole, Imperial Wharf: they're playing Winds of Change by The Scorpions ......

wayneJ @Pharma - I think we should send out search parties for Murph.....just wondering if paving stones near Imperial Wharf need to be dug up....
Soundbuy 'Winds of Change ' ........There's a message in there, some where...........
Excel Developer @BE: I'm tempted to make a prank phone call to your new office.
wayneJ Thinking out aloud and would love others views - Hunt has suggested a hard Brexit may be negative for GBP - what are the best equity ways to play this?

I hate London.

Excel Developer Moe: [answering the phone] Moe's Tavern.Bart: Hello, is Al there?Moe: Al?Bart: Yes, Al. Last name: Coholic.Moe: Let me check... [calls] Phone call for Al. Al Coholic. Is there an Al Coholic here?

What else?

cloudy @wayneJ - sin stocks I would say.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Should probably mention On The Beach, which is up sharply on a profit warning.

On The Beach Group PLC (OTB:LSE): Last: 470.25, up 58.75 (+14.28%), High: 478.50, Low: 415.00, Volume: 2.06m
BE11:39am

Also buying something called Classic Collection for £20m

wayneJ What happens to eg travel cos - can Brits afford to go abroad - so would it be negative? Also thinking unless we have clarity by Oct / Nov then peak summer holiday booking season could be choas - ie will you know if you will be able to travel / visa issues etc for next year's summer hols?
11:39 am
BE11:40am

Which sells "dynamically packaged luxury beach holidays, distributed offline through travel agents (high street and homeworkers)."

BE11:40am

That's as per Panmure Gordon, which continues:

BE11:40am

Company accounts show Classic reported a 4.0% operating margin in 2017, more consistent with Thomas Cook (3.7%) and TUI (5.9%) than OTB (34%); with operating profit shrinking by 2.6% on 3.4% revenue growth in 2017. The timing feels opportunistic, with new regulation (Package Travel Directive) expected to make life more onerous for independent agents.

chad_john People still do use travel agents. It's frightening.
11:41 am
BE11:41am

T he strategic rationale surprised us somewhat, compared to the more natural bolt on of the Sunshine OTA for £12m in 2017. But on the conference call management outlined a credible case for targeting the UK offline market (TAM c.5m customers), in particular by developing a ‘Classic Online’ portal for travel agents to access OTB’s core mainstream holiday product, i.e. a B2B not B2C site (expected launch 1Q19). The existing Classic business has limited overlap with OTB given its luxury bias. The accounts suggest higher working capital intensity than OTB, but management say Classic does not take inventory risk. Agent commission equates to c.50% of revenue – not dissimilar to OTB’s level of marketing spend.

Grouchmonkey @wayneJ inconceivable you won't be able to travel but exchange rate and cost is a tricky one for the companies: presumably they have to take a view or hedge in Oct/Nov?
wayneJ @Chad - There is value in packaging airlines plus hotels etc.
Pharma @wayneJ. Really? You assign a probability above zero to the EU cutting off transportation links and demanding visas in the event no deal is signed? Amazing that remainers have such a low opinion of the EU.
BE11:42am

As for trading -- it's largely known. Hot weather and World Cup ....

BE11:43am

But OTB can cut marketing spend to meet forecasts, so FY targets are unchanged.

wayneJ @grouch - am thinking if say it appeared that 'Visas' to New Europe cost £50 per head would that impact behaviour? +/- currency fall - admittedly it already has quite significantly
Soundbuy @Chad - bizarrely yes, all seem to be pretty full locally, stranded between the charity shops and Tattoo parlours...
11:43 am
BE11:43am

Numis incoming:

Excel Developer Barista: [answering the phone] Harris & Hoole, Imperial Wharf.Bart: Hello, is Milly there?Barista: Milly?Bart: Yes, Milly. Last name: Ennial.Barista: Let me check... [calls] Phone call for Milly. Milly Ennial. Is there an Milly Ennial here?
wayneJ Remember I am talking about the edge - but even a few % less booking in Dec - March for next summer could wipe out profits of the travel cos.?
BE11:44am

Given the sustained heatwave in the UK and warnings from peers, we are reassured that OTB expects FY18 PBT to be "broadly in line with management expectations". This is testament to its flexible business model and ability to flex marketing spend as appropriate. Nevertheless, we consider it prudent to trim our FY18 PBT forecast by 2% to £33.5m to the bottom of the tight consensus range. Including c. £400k contribution from 'Classic', we now forecast FY18E PBT of £33.9m. Our FY19 and FY20 forecasts do not yet include any contribution from Classic Collection.

BE11:44am

OTB shares have fallen by 37% since its interims in May,
with expectations, we believe, of a profit warning which today's statement clearly dispels. Today's acquisition demonstrates management's ambition to expand its addressable market leveraging its existing tech capabilities. With the shares trading on 15.9x FY19E PER (c.15.5x including accretion) we reiterate our BUY recommendation.

11:44 am
undefined
AGA Any thoughts on Bayer here?
wayneJ @Pharm - I am not saying a 'cut off' - but rather uncertainty re visas / health / travel insurance / weak currency etc
AGA isn't it the deepest discount in any mega cap now?
Patience @wayneJ - agreed. Avoid stress by planning UK holiday in 2019.
Penny @JD i had the same thoughts re GOCO. Maybe explains the bounce back. Zoopla already tried to buy it (twice, I think).
LK Hyman @J Chisholm Thanks for the clarification! I withdraw my accusation of it being a cormorant (no shag either).
BE11:47am

@AGA: we've done a bit on Bayer over the past couple of days, to be found here: https://www.ft.com/stocks-to-watch

Pharma @wayneJ I just think the uncertainty is confected.
wayneJ @Patience - Glasgow beckons....wonder if Bryce has a favourite spot....
wayneJ @BE - one or more of the big banks are doing expert conference calls on Bayer and the implications.

In short, there's a rational argument (that glyphosate risks aren't huge, based on the best evidence available)

Excel Developer (traces of) glyphosate found in USA Cheerios re the Guradian.
casapinos @BE Rational argument 0 US juries 1
chopper bear anything on centamin ?

Note, also, the god awful reporting about glyphosate that's now happening

Think this increases the pressure for Tencent to push some of its games from Europe into the Chinese mkt (UK and French sourced) - which could set up next year to be very interesting.

AGA @BE thanks. Surprised big cash pools don't step in. Seems very American to trash crown jewels once they are out of US
J L Any news on Deutsche Bank? Looks attractive below 10 Euro. US Banks mostly recovered since 2010 but not European ones.
BE11:55am

If you want to buy Bayer amid all this noise, fair enough. But I'd not expect it to move back to anything approaching a fair value for quite some time.

Soundbuy 'Safe Limits' .............hmmmmm
Pharma @wayneJ, the ones I have seen were merely stating the obvious. Don't use "Roundup" interchangeably with "glyphosate", because the tests have been done on glyphosate (as they have to be), not the various formulations Roundup sold (some of which do not even contain glyphosate).They've been taken out of context.
11:55 am
undefined
Lemmy litigation risk exists but bigger concern for Bayer may be legislation as more and more countries look to ban/regulate glyphosate
wayneJ @Pharma - there are some where it seems to imply the co will write a 'report' and get a scientist to 'sign' it as if it is his independent expert opinion. And others about 'managing' various regulators / bodies etc
chopper bear i did buy buyer this morning - but i have a terrible habit of buying too early :-(
wayneJ There is also an amusing one about hiring a series of experts to refute the litigation (at an earlier stage) and they make a comment that the cost (it was either $250k or $2m - can't remember which) was too much.... bet the number looks cheap now
J L Hence the name @Chopper Bear ;-)
Pharma @wayneJ. Not seen those. Corporate idiocy in action.
BE11:59am

The dreadlocked chap from the white rum brand has now left, having first delighted his audience with tales of novelty cocktails delivered via the crotch region and speculation about how the aging process has affected the physicality of various actresses they might consider suitable for the ad campaign .....

BE11:59am

.... I'm not going to name the white rum brand, of course.

11:59 am
Diageo PLC (DGE:LSE): Last: 2,777, up 12 (+0.43%), High: 2,778, Low: 2,763, Volume: 561.16k
undefined
chopper bear *bayer
Pharma (doesn't change the science that there is no evidence glyphosate is a significant cancer risk)
LK Hyman I use RoundUp all the time. Put on a pair of gumboots, have a shower afterwards, no worries.
Flaneur @Pharma - youre talking down the outrage industry with that sort of comment.
Pharma Ultimately, all cancers are caused by oxygen. Perhaps there is scope for a ban.
BE12:01pm

Are we missing anything? There's the pound, I guess, which has broken its losing run.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

On retail sales.

wayneJ @Pharma - three different hurdles - legal / scientific / regulatory......with different thresholds. Also the individual in question actually had two specific accidents where he was covered with the chemicals in question - which I suspect is not done in any trials. I do wonder if it has any reflection on the relatively low doses eg in food
LK Hyman @BE It's Captain Morgan innit? Hence your Diageo reference?
Flaneur I read something about Elephants and cancer this morning... they dont get it apparently.. or something. DYOR.
BE12:02pm

Which aren't as terrible as expected. here's HSBC.

BE12:03pm

UK retail sales rose 0.7% m-o-m in June (consensus: 0.0%), while volumes excluding fuel rose
0.9% (consensus: 0.2%).
This took the 3m/3m rate to 2.1% (both including and excluding fuel) - a three and a half year high
(Chart 1) and keeps volumes well above last year's trend (Chart 2).
The strongest growth was in non-store retailing (+5.9% m-o-m) and textiles, clothing and footwear
shops (+2.7% m-o-m).
The latter was also the sector which saw the heaviest discounting, with implied prices down 3.1%
m-o-m and flat on the year (Chart 3).
Overall retail sales inflation (excluding fuel) fell to a 17-month low of 1.0% y-o-y. This is a fairly
sharp fall from 2.0% in April and 3.0% in November 2017.
But fuel prices were up 11.9% y-o-y - a 16-month high.

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

For us, this is a surprisingly strong reading, given the strength in volumes over Q2 and the fact that
consumer confidence edged down again in July. Given that annual real wage growth was still
around zero in the latest data, we would have expected a little more pay-back for April and May.
But this is a relatively strong start to the third quarter, which will bolster the BoE's view that the
economy is back on track. Further out, we see inflation inching back a little further, giving some
support to real wages (at least taking them into positive territory). But still, we find it hard to see
this above trend growth being maintained over the remainder of the year, particularly as higher
petrol and energy costs - and possibly food bills as well - may hit confidence even as the headline
CPI rate comes down.

undefined
Pharma @wayneJ, no indeed; the trials tend to be done by adding huge doses to the food of mice that are genetically predisposed to cancer.Would think that doses would in any case be higher through inhaling than bathing. Skin tends to be fairly proof against water soluble chemicals.
wayneJ I have seen severe contact dermatitis reactions from simple household chemicals
Blank canvas thanks for everything today. Last day tomorrow before BE's summer hols
wayneJ Was wondering if in this individual the initial reaction lead to a prolonged immune reaction. Also I wonder if the second exposure is the critical trigger event?
LK Hyman Monsanto reps used to drink neat RoundUp as a party trick, or so I was told. I wonder how many of 'em suffered any aftereffects?
FJ I do feel sorry for Einhorn going under with his disastrous Bayer investment.
GBKrona thanks @BE, ROTR
BE12:06pm

That'll do. I need to go file a story then get the hell out of this glass and concrete commuter hellscene.

Excel Developer cheers bye
Manxish Thanks BE, Rabble

12:06 pm
BE12:07pm

BE12:07pm

Afternoon all.

Pharma @wayneJ, or perhaps he is just one of the unfortunate 15% (i.e. a large number of people) who get this sort of cancer in their 40s & 50s.
